page.title: 03HAM HOUSE
page.content: {Ham House}is situated at the end of Ham Street, beside the river. It was built in 1610 for Elizabeth, Countess of Dysart and Duchess of Lauderdale. After the Dysarts the Tollemache family lived in Ham House. The family remained there until 1948 when their properties in Ham and Petersham were sold by auction. Ham House with its grounds were given to the National Trust and the contents were bought by the government for the Victoria and Albert Museum. It is now furnished and decorated entirely in 17th.Century works, many of them original to Ham House. Now Ham House is open to the public for tours and visits. The riverside gardens of Ham House are still looked after and are beautiful in the summer in full bloom.
